section: This Website Design, Development and Hosting Agreement the ("Agreement") is entered into on January 11, 2018 by and between Natalija Tunevic, director of FreeCook (hereinafter referred to as "Client") and Mitchell Vitalis, director of Mitchell's Web Advance, PLC (hereinafter referred to as "Service Provider").
explanation: This section defines the parties to the agreement. However, the acronym used to refer to Mitchell's Web Advance is "Service Provider" when it should more accurately be "Company", as "Company" is used throughout the rest of the agreement. This misalignment of terms introduces confusion because "Service Provider" is never used again, yet it is presented as if it is going to be used.

section: Terms of the project: 12 weeks from February 8, 2018 to May 3, 2018.
explanation: This sets out the agreed project timeline. However, the term "Terms of the project" is ambiguous as it is not defined in the document. Additionally, it is used to introduce only the duration of the project, when one would reasonably expect "terms" to also cover obligations and expectations. This term is therefore structurally flawed, as it does not provide the reader with any additional expectations or obligations outside of the project timeline.

section: Client agrees to pay to Company the sum of $5,000. Client shall make a prepayment of $1,900 and pay the remaining $3,100 on completion of the Scope of Work.
explanation: While not a direct contradiction within the text itself, this payment schedule lacks specificity, creating potential ambiguity and leading to disputes. The section refers to "completion of the Scope of Work," but provides no specific acceptance criteria or clear definition of what constitutes 'completion.' This ambiguity can allow Company to argue the work is complete (thus triggering final payment) when Client has reasonable grounds to believe the Scope of Work hasn't been fully satisfied. The lack of specificity and acceptance criteria creates an in-text contradiction, as other portions of the document rely on the completion of the scope of work, yet the definition is missing.
